indicators.justification:
New Zealand's Greenhouse Gas Inventory is produced each year as part of New Zealand's obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the Kyoto Protocol. The inventory is the key source of evidence on New Zealand's greenhouse gas emissions trends. New Zealand's inventory data are used for both international and domestic reporting(1). The Inventory measures New Zealand's progress against obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the Kyoto Protocol. The Inventory adheres to the UNFCCC reporting guidelines and the international methodology guidelines set out by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The Inventory is the official source of New Zealand's emissions and removals data and is reported annually to the UNFCCC. It is also the basis by which progress towards targets is determined. Data is available from 1990, in line with international reporting requirements. Emissions and removals projections are also produced and reported every two years(2). The Inventory contains information about sectors (Agriculture, Energy, Industrial Processes and Product Use (IPPU), Waste, Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry (LULUCF) and Other (Tokelau), as well as Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry under the Kyoto Protocol (KP-LULUCF)(3). It contains detailed information on sources of greenhouse gas emissions and details of land use effects on emissions(4). Since the Climate Change Response (Zero Carbon) Amendment Act 2019 came into force, however, NZ has also begun tracking progress against our domestic targets(5). New Zealand's Interactive Emissions Tracker summarises the data from the Inventory(6)

1. NZ Ministry for the Environment. May 2021. New Zealand's Greenhouse Gas Inventory 1990-2019. https://environment.govt.nz/publications/new-zealands-greenhouse-gas-inventory-1990-2019/

2. NZ StatsNZ. 2020. Approaches to measuring New Zealand's greenhouse gas emissions.  https://www.stats.govt.nz/methods/approaches-to-measuring-new-zealands-greenhouse-gas-emissions

3. NZ Ministry for the Environment. 2021. Te whakarāpopototanga tuihono o Te Rārangi Haurehu Kati Mahana a Aotearoa 1990–2019: New Zealand's Greenhouse Gas Inventory Snapshot 1990–2019. https://environment.govt.nz/publications/new-zealands-greenhouse-gas-inventory-1990-2019-snapshot/

4. NZ Ministry for the Environment. 2021. About New Zealand's greenhouse gas inventory. https://environment.govt.nz/facts-and-science/climate-change/measuring-greenhouse-gas-emissions/about-new-zealands-greenhouse-gas-inventory/

5. NZ Ministry for the Environment. 2021. New Zealand's projected greenhouse gas emissions to 2050.  https://environment.govt.nz/what-government-is-doing/areas-of-work/climate-change/emissions-reduction-targets/new-zealands-projected-greenhouse-gas-emissions-to-2050/

6. NZ Ministry for the Environment. 2021. New Zealand's Interactive Emissions Tracker. https://emissionstracker.mfe.govt.nz/#NrAMBoEYF12TwCIByBTALo2wBM4eiQCc2AHEltEA

indicators.justification:
The NZ Threat Classification System (NZTCS) database is  released by the NZ Department of Conservation(1). The database covers mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, invertebrates, fungi, vascular and non-vascular plants and the data classifications include "Recovering' species. The data is free of charge, openly licensed under a Creative Commmons Attribution CC BY 4.0 International licences, and can be downloaded in xlsx format. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species(2) includes some of NZ's endangered species but has different processes and criteria.(3). Over the survey period NZ scientists worked actively to add endangered fungi to the IUCN list(4). There is also an active local community(5). A new Climate Impact qialifier has been added to the NZTCS(6).

indicators.justification:
Government agencies, StatsNZ(1), the Ministry for the Environment(2) and the Crown Research Institute, National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research Limited(3-5) release climate vulnerability and future climate information as open data. New Zealand's regional government agencies notify their hazard zones(5). Social Vulnerability Indicators(6) and the New Zealand Socioeconomic Deprivation Index(7-8) map vulnerability to climate change. A 2021 paper proposes a novel approach to developing social vulnerability indicators, using the example of flooding in Aotearoa New Zealand(9).

indicators.justification:
Picking up on their commitment at the 2016 London Anticorruption Summit to "explore the establishment of a public central register of company beneficial ownership information", the NZ Government in 2018 released a Discussion Document: Increasing the Transparency of the Beneficial Ownership of New Zealand Companies and Limited Partnerships,  noting that information about the beneficial ownership of companies and limited partnerships is not collected by the NZ Companies Office, although the Companies Registrar can request it for law enforcement purposes(1). The public submissions on the Discussion Document were released on 25 June 2019, with a statement anticipating decisions from the Government by the end of 2019(2). Interest.co reported in January 2020 that the Minister of Commerce and Consumer Affairs was expecting Cabinet decisions in the second quarter of 2020(3). In July 2020, Transparency International ran a webinar on the issue(4). Over this time, COVID 19 intervened, followed by the October 2020 general election. In May 2021, the Institute of Directors reported that this work has been combined with another MBIE initiative considering the introduction of director identification numbers(5). There have been no public statements to this effect by the government.

Sources:
1. NZ. Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment. 2018. Discussion Document: Increasing the Transparency of the Beneficial Ownership of New Zealand Companies and Limited Partnerships. https://www.mbie.govt.nz/dmsdocument/2905-increasing-the-transparency-of-the-beneficial-ownership-of-new-zealand-companies-and-limited-partnerships-pdf
2. NZ. Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment. 2019. Have your say: increasing the transparency of the beneficial ownership of New Zealand companies and limited partnerships. https://www.mbie.govt.nz/have-your-say/increasing-the-transparency-of-the-beneficial-ownership-of-new-zealand-companies-and-limited-partnerships/
3. Interest.co. 2020. MBIE officials wrestling with cost issues as government efforts to bolster the transparency of the beneficial ownership of New Zealand companies and limited partnerships, but not trusts, drag on. https://www.interest.co.nz/business/103358/mbie-officials-working-cost-issues-government-move-increase-transparency-beneficial
4. Transparency International. 2020. A matter of trust: beneficial ownership in New Zealand. https://www.transparency.org.nz/blog/matter-trust-beneficial-ownership-new-zealand
5. NZ. Institute of Directors. 2021. Improving the Transparency of Beneficial Ownership. https://www.iod.org.nz/resources-and-insights/policy-and-legal/policy-and-bills/improving-the-transparency-of-beneficial-ownership/#

indicators.justification:
Anyone can generally request copies of someone's information in New Zealand's Births Deaths and Marriages register(1). Full online access to historic records is available (2). The Mortality Collection (MORT) combines death registration and stillbirth registration data with cause of death information which is then collated and coded to create national cause of death statistics(3). StatsNZ's Infoshare database includes detailed birth and mortality statistics which can be downloaded in bulk as csv files(4)(5). Personal information is not made available online.

3. NZ Ministry of Health. 2021. Mortality Collection. https://www.health.govt.nz/nz-health-statistics/national-collections-and-surveys/collections/mortality-collection.

indicators.justification:
New Zealand's public health services are delivered by 20 District Health Boards which report annually and must meet performance standards set by the Ministry of Health MOH)(1). Basic details of each DHB's facilites are available as an xlsx spreadsheet(2). Ventilators and ICU beds as at May 2020 are available(3). Although MOH says this is the most current information(4), a media article sets out more recent data and there is no official 2021 data(5). COVID-19 testing(6) and vaccination(7) data are updated weekly and StatsNZ's COVID-19 data portal provides graph, tables, downloads and API functionality(8). indicators.justification:
Pfizer/BioNTech is New Zealand's primary vaccine provider. As at 28 July, only the Pfizer/BioNTech and Janssen vaccines have been provisionally approved by Medsafe. However, the Pfizer vaccine is the only vaccine that Cabinet has approved for rollout in New Zealand(1). Everyone in New Zealand aged 16 and over is in 1 of 4 groups for their COVID-19 vaccinations(2). Aggregate weekly graphs and xlsx spreadsheets are released for each group, including by age, gender, ethnicity and region (District Health Board)(3). 80 downloadable COVID-19 data portal indicators, including national health data, are available via the Stats NZ open data API(4). However, the data from the 20 District Health Boards, including denominator data, is inconsistent and incomplete, with the medical profession and the media urging more accurate and useful data in May 2021(5).

indicators.justification:
The LINZ Data Service (LDS) provides free online access to New Zealand's most up-to-date land and seabed data, including property data.(1). To access ownership information, users must first agree to using the LINZ Licence for Personal Data(2). This allows access to the NZ Property Title Including Owners and NZ Property Title Owners datasets in the LINZ Data Service(3). LINZ offers users an open search of the restricted Landonline database to find a title, instrument or survey. A copy of the record which includes the name of the property owner can be purchased for $5(4).

The LDS NZ Property titles list includes Māori land. Note that a total of 27,000 total Māori land blocks are registered with LINZ in Landonline, representing about 99 percent of the total inventory of Māori freehold land. Māori Land Online is the free online register of Māori land titles held by the Māori Land Court, and any registered title held by LINZ(5). It provides a snapshot of current ownership, trustee, memorial and block information for land that falls within the jurisdiction of the Māori Land Court under Te Ture Whenua Māori Act 1993 and other legislation. Information on land concessions and/or leases is in the LDS NZ Title Memorials List(6). The official site is at the Māori Land Court(7). The LDS data can be downloaded in bulk and via an API. Māori Land Online data is made available in 1 of 2 spatial formats, a shapefile and a geodatabase, is ESRI compatible and maybe downloaded and imported into mapping applications. The Central Record of State Land prototype uses information that is held by all government agencies, and is also available via an official information act request(8).  Our Maps, published by the Walking Access Commision, gives a public view of accessible areas, tracks, conservation land and property information across New Zealand(9).

indicators.justification:
New Zealand publishes all of its Crown financial statements as structured data(1). The data is free of charge and openly licensed with a Creative Commmons CC BY 4.0 International licence. This includes budget data(2), expenditure data(3), social services and community sector(4). For the OBS and GDB 4 funds are classified  as extra budgetary funds: Earthquake Commission, Accident Compensation Commission, NZ Superannuation Fund and the Government Superannuation Fund. With New Zealand's consolidated Accrual accounting these are included in the consolidated Total Crown ex ante and ex post accrual financial statements which also include companies that are partly or fully government owned(5). Budget entries' administrative, economic, functional and programme classifications are generally compatible with international standards(6)(7)(8). The most recent budget update(9) and interim Financial Statements(10) are in May 2021. Machine-readable historical data is available from 1972(11).

indicators.justification:
NZ's election expenditure is well documented(1) and commented on (2). Individual party donations above specified levels are released as open data in xlxs format(3). Party loans over $30,000 are released in html and pdf format(4). Election spending by candidate is released as xlxs(5). There is a searchable online election candidate dashboard for the 2020 election expenditure(6). Party election broadcasting funding is released as a pdf document(7). Data on travel and accommodation and credit card expenses for Ministers of the Crown is released quarterly(8). Data on travel and accommodation expenses for Members of Parliament are administered and released quarterly by the Parliamentary Service and Office of the Clerk(9).

indicators.justification:
Agencies are applying Government's 2017 Expectations for Regulatory Stewardship(1) regarding "appropriate opportunities to comment throughout the proposed regulatory change process in different ways. indicators.justification:
The government procurement data website and the government open data portal (data.govt.nz) offer some of New Zealand's central and local government procurement data(1). The tender types of 'Request for Proposals', 'Requests for Quotations', 'Requests for Tenders' and 'Award Notices' are included and the release includes tenders from agencies that are mandated, expected and encouraged to use the GETS tendering service. Procurement relating to goods and services and public works is included. Users must register on GETS to access more detailed information, respond to tenders and manage notifications for new opportunities in categories and/or regions of interest(2). Exemptions are listed in the Government's Procurement Rules(3)(4). In the current dataset, the Awarded Amount field is empty, and the Company awarded the contract, when identified, is only noted in the Comments field(5). The machine-readable dataset is free, openly licenced using Creative Commons Attribution CC BY 4.0 International Licence, and GETS schema and documentation tools are provided.(6) Historic data files are provided for the period 29 July 2014 (the date of the first award notice on GETS) to 30 June 2019(7). In January 2021, the annual total of contract values published on the Government Electronic Tenders Service was $1.016 billion, which was just 2.5% of the total annual government expenditure. This means that the financial details of 97.5% of government expenditure are not reported(8).

indicators.justification:
The Data and Digital — agile, innovative and accessible workstream of the Strategy for a Digital Public Service supports and encourages data reuse (1). Government policy supports and encourages government data re-use through the Reusable Principle of the government's Cabinet mandated NZ Data and Information Management Principles(2).  The NZ government's open data action plan 2017-2020 aimed "to develop an open data enabling environment and accelerate the use and reuse of open government data so that NZ is maximising the value of open data"(3).

GovHacks were held in 2019(4) and 2020(5). The NZ government's primary role was to ensure that its data was reusable and guide participants to that data. Central government has supported open government data reuse since 2010 when it released the NZ Government Open Access and Licensing framework (NZGOAL)(6). The Open data showcase on the Open government data portal sets out case studies of reuse of its data(7). The Government Open Data Portal promotes the benefits of open data use by the private sector, start-ups, NGOs and the not for profit sector(8). The NZ GovTech Accelerator programme, led by Creative HQ over the last three years, included a data challenge project in 2020(9). The 2020 independent report on the closure of the open data programme listed the increased subscription and participation numbers in meetups around NZ over 2017-2020(10).

indicators.justification:
The government's open information and data programme commenced in 2009(1). Over the GDB survey period, they worked to the Open Government Data Action Plan 2017-2020(2). It ceased as a separate programme in July 2020 and has continued as an ongoing commitment of the Government Chief Data Steward without its own budget(3). The StatsNZ 2020 annual report has added a new performance measure for Open datasets released on data.govt.nz by government agencies(4). The government portal is well maintained(5). Its Data Toolkit includes an Open Data Release Checklist and Formats for Open Data(6). The most recent public evidence of political support was in 2018 when the Minister of Statistics Hon James Shaw and Government Chief Data Steward (GCDS) Liz MacPherson publicly co-signed New Zealand's Open Data Charter letter(7). StatsNZ is a member of the international Open Data Expert Group(8). Central government agencies are directed or encouraged to apply open data policy and local government agencies encouraged. They have listed 28,587 datasets on the government open data portal(9).

2. NZ Government. 2017. Open Data Action Plan. https://data.govt.nz/toolkit/open-data/open-data-nz/open-data-action-plan/

indicators.justification:
Local government in New Zealand consists of 78 local, regional and unitary councils, all of which manage their own data(1). No local government open data policies have been located online. However, major councils and regions have Open Data Portals which offer downloadable data licensed with the Creative Commmons CC BY Attribution 4.0 International Licence, in accordance with the Cabinet approved NZ Government Open Access and Licensing framewowrk (NZGOAL) which local councils were invited to adopt(2). Initially the Data Strategy and Roadmap of New Zealand examines the government's role in enabling a well-functioning central government data system. This will broaden over time to include non-government organisations (NGOs), local government, and the private sector(3). Until then, councils set their own rules and guidance in accordance with the Privacy Act 2020(4). New Zealand's Public Records regulatory system covers all NZ public offices including local authorities(5)(6). Many councils partner with the 20/20 Trust to deliver Digital Inclusion programmes throughout Aotearoa, NZ(7). The local council open data portals offer machine-readable datasets that are openly licensed, many publicised on the Government Open Data Portal, data.govt.nz and supplied to the Land Information NZ (LINZ) Data Service. This geospatial data is frequently downloaded in bulk for re-use using the LINZ API(8)(9).

indicators.justification:
Under the Companies Act 1993, the companies register has publicly available information on company directors and some shareholders(1). Under the Limited Partnerships Act 2008, the limited partnerships register has publicly available information on general partners(2). This information can sometimes be sufficient to identify a beneficial owner, although generally only for corporate entities that are at low risk of being involved in money laundering. Information about beneficial owners is not collected  although the Companies Registrar can request it for law enforcement purposes(3). Consequently there are no provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields, data quality, openness, timing, and structure though these are canvassed in Section 5: Key design features of the Discussion Paper(4).

indicators.justification:
Part 7 of the Privacy Act 2020 covers Sharing, accessing, and matching personal information(1). It provides for an Approved Information Sharing Agreement (AISA) that allows personal information to be shared between (or within) agencies within New Zealand for the purpose of delivering public services. The definition of agency covers government agencies and  private organisations. At least 1 of the agencies that enters into an AISA must be a public sector agency(2). The Act also gives the Privacy Commissioner the power to issue codes of practice that become part of the law. These codes modify the operation of the Privacy Act and set rules for specific industries, organisations, or types of personal information. There are currently six codes of practice (3). Sections 174-191 covers authorised information matching programmes which is "the comparison (whether manually or by means of any electronic or other device) of any document that contains personal information about 10 or more individuals with 1 or more other documents that contain personal information about 10 or more individuals, for the purpose of producing or verifying information that may be used for the purpose of taking adverse action against an identifiable individual."(4) The Privacy Act covers all government agencies, and many themes and provides national coverage.

1. Privacy Act. 2020. Part 7. Sharing, accessing, and matching personal information. https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2020/0031/latest/LMS23223.html?src=qs

3. NZ. Privacy Commissioner. 2021. Codes of Practice. https://www.privacy.org.nz/privacy-act-2020/codes-of-practice/

indicators.justification:
The 2020 Privacy Act, which applies across New Zealand and covers public and private data holders, came into force on 1 December 2020(1). It "affords New Zealanders better privacy protections, and organisations and businesses greater obligations when handling personal information" and "gives the Privacy Commissioner greater powers to ensure organisations and businesses comply with the Act".(2) It sets out twelve privacy  information principles covering rights of choice or consent, rights to access and correct personal data, rights of redress and notification of data breaches and responsibilities for data holders(3). It also gives the Privacy Commissioner the power to issue codes of practice that become part of the law. These codes modify the operation of the Privacy Act and set rules for specific industries, organisations, or types of personal information(4).
Complaints, investigations, and proceedings are set out in Part 5 (5). The Privacy Act does not cover location-related data, other than allowing law enforcement authorities to reveal location for vehicles of interest, missing persons (for fines enforcement), and records of prisoners(6). Privacy, ethics and human rights are safeguarded in the government's voluntary Algorithm Charter for Aotearoa New Zealand to which 26 government agencies have signed up(7). This Charter complements the 2018 Principles for the safe and effective use of data and analytics(8). No impact assessment of the Charter has been completed in this survey period. The Privacy Commissioner has published a very extensive range of publications describing the Privacy Act 2020(9). On 6 July 2021 the Government announced it would implement a new legislative framework for a consumer data right following public consultation on a 2020 Discussion Paper(10), (11). New Zealand Geospatial Research and Development Priorities and Opportunities 2016 – 2020 states that obstacles to increasing the uptake and use of geospatial information include concerns about data privacy, data ownership, the liability for the use of data and data confidentiality(12).

indicators.justification:
In June 2021, New Zealand (NZ)'s comprehensive open data framework comprises a suite of open data policies, approved by the NZ Cabinet. These are the 2010 (updated 2014) NZ Government Open Access and Licensing (NZGOAL) framework, the 2011 Declaration on Open and Transparent Government, the 2011 NZ Data and Information Management Principles and NZ's adoption in 2017 of the Open Data Charter, which are all available online, together with some relevant Cabinet Papers and Minutes(1). Central government agencies are directed or encouraged to apply these policies and local government invited. Over 150 agencies now publicise their data on data.govt.nz(2). Ownership of these policies is now an ongoing commitment of the Government Chief Data Steward (also the Government Statistician)(3). The separate NZ Open Government Information and Data Programme ran from 2009 until 30 June 2020. Its 2017-2020 Open Data Action Plan had three goals: increase access to government held data, increase use of data, and build an open by design culture(4). Its Releasing Open Data Checklist is a notable output(5). Work updating the action plan is underway(6). The open data pages on digital.govt.nz also link to this work(7).

indicators.justification:
New Zealand's public finance legal framework is set out in the Public Finance Act 1989(1), Crown Entities Act 2004(2) and the State-Owned Enterprises Act 1986(3). Each Act mandates clear collecting and publishing requirements but makes no mention of structured data. The Treasury's Guide to the Public Finance Act(4) describes the Act and Treasury Instructions, Section 6.2 sets out agency reporting obligations(5). indicators.justification:
New Zealand has no lobbying legislative or regulatory framework(1). The closest requirement is for regular visitors to gain approval by the Speaker of the House of Representatives for a Visitors Card which includes some lobbyists but not all(2),(3). indicators.justification:
NZ's Electoral Act 1993, Part 6A has mandatory requirements for election expenses and donations(1). The Department of Internal Affairs issues AML-CFT guidance on election financing(2). The Electoral Commission issues guidance(3) and rules on election expenses and donations(4) and reports on party expenditure(5-6). The NZ Serious Fraud Office investigates political party donations that appear to not comply with the legislation and guidelines(7). The regulated election expenses  incurred  for  each  campaign  represent but a fraction of the total that will actually be spent on seeking election. The  full  extent  of  such  expenditure  is  shrouded in mystery as candidates, parties and  promoters  are  required  to  publicly  report  only  on  their  election  expenses  following  each  contest,  not  their  full  campaign accounts(8). There is extensive political and media discussion on this topic(9-12).

indicators.justification:
Despite New Zealand's lower level of the GDB's set of political integrity data, what is available is being used to identify, expose, or highlight failures of government. Funding of election campaigns is well documented, due to a three-yearly electoral cycle, publicly released campaign data by the Electoral Commission and consequent actions by the Serious Fraud Office(1). There is regular academic interest in vested interests and political donations(2-4) and to Official Information Act (OIA) requests and complaints data(5). Civil society also comments regularly on political donations and Official Information Act requests and complaints data(6-7). Māori researchers also express concern about OIA statistics(8-9). The Prime Minister signalled electoral law changes in May 2021 following the Serious Fraud Office's announcement it was looking into four political parties' donations(10).

indicators.justification:
The NZ Government committed to making procurement data more accessible in Commitment Twelve of New Zealand's  Open Government Partnership National Action Plan 2018-2020(1)(2). Two major civil society and peak groups are analysing government procurement data to improve procurement practice. They are Transparency International NZ and NZ Rise, which represents NZ-owned IT companies. Transparency International NZ has analysed the NZ open procurement data since its first release in July 2019(3) and made regular postings over this period(4). NZ Rise has also analysed the data and urged the government to release data about all of government's procurement contracts(5) and discussed the impact of the lack of complete data for communities including Maori and Pacifica(6).

Sources
1. NZ Government. 2018. Open Government Partnership National Action Plan 2018-2020. Commitment Twelve: Open Procurement. https://ogp.org.nz/assets/Publications/OGP-National-Action-Plan-2018-2020.pdf

2. NZ Ministry of Business Innovation and Employment. 2020. Making government procurement data more accessible. https://www.data.govt.nz/blog/making-procurement-data-more-accessible/

3. Transparency International NZ. NZ government contract award notices July 2019 - March 2021. 
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1p6cver8O7i6n0fRKLGB1dPKgsPvmdWNZyYHGXMgTYro/edit#gid=1574116384

4. Transparency International NZ. 2021. BETTER GOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT IN 2021. https://www.transparency.org.nz/blog/better-government-procurement-in-2021

5. NZ Rise. 2019. Government procurement awards released as open data. https://nzrise.org.nz/government-procurement-awards-released-as-open-data/

6. NZ Rise. 2021. The impact of Government Procurement exemptions. https://nzrise.org.nz/the-impact-of-government-procurement-exemptions/
